div.p: Bibliothèque de l'Institut de France, Paris.

It was extremely generous, honored and venerable friend, that you sent me your only specimen of Restio pilisepalus, which (as I anticipated in fragm, VIII, 99) does not belong to the genus Restio and which, — as I now see from your specimen, does not even belong to the order, but belongs to Cyperoideae and most probably to the genus Chaetospora. I did not venture to dissect more that one spikelet, in which I found one male and one bisexual flower. Steudel took the filaments (of which there however three) together with the hypogynous plumous setulae (of which there are six) for sepals. The fruit is not broad and 2 or three celled and dehiscent, as in Restio, but a one seeded caryopsis. Doubltless the petioles are not slit in this plant, but unopened cylindrical this however cannot be ascertained from the material at your disposal. I now return gratefully the whole specimen, and thank you for the disinterested manner, in which you sent me this precious exemplar.
May providence give you yet many years life and strength to continue your luminous path in science; that is the ardent wish of your regardful
